nytimes_articles.headline: Bronx School Struggles Despite Praise and Fame
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everywhere, the children make music. They stroke the keys in the piano room and they caress violins in the auditorium. They sing in the musty, peeling theater built in 1914 where, just outside the door, beleaguered men gather along Boston Road and dogs sleep on the sidewalk.   St. Augustine School of the Arts, a nationally renowned Roman Catholic elementary school in the South Bronx, is experiencing the best and worst of times. An award-winning documentary about the school opened in New York on Friday, and the school's principal was recently honored as one of the nation's outstanding educators. But a fire last December that destroyed two-thirds of the main school building has left St. Augustine struggling to maintain its financial footing.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Veterans, a Time for Memories; A Hospital's Small Celebration Turns Into a Day for Sharing
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a veterans hospital, the wars sometimes never end, and memories are carried deep in lasting wounds and lost years.   "Memorial Day is different when you get in here," said Andy Giannone, who came back from the dark terror of the Vietnam jungle as a heroin addict 25 years ago and who spent his first sober Memorial Day in years at a small celebration here today.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. GETS PROTEST ON CAMBODIA VOTE
nytimes_articles.abstract: With new vote totals showing a neck-and-neck race between Cambodia's ruling party and the royalist opposition founded by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Government protested to the United Nations today what it said were "irregularities" in last week's elections.    Although the United Nations, several foreign governments and a variety of independent poll monitors have certified the voting as free and fair, diplomats in Phnom Penh warned that the Government was laying the groundwork for a claim that the election results should be annulled and that it might try to hold power even if it lost at the polls.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Gentler China: A special report.; 4 Years After Tiananmen, The Hard Line Is Cracking
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly four years have passed since the Communist hard-liners sent tanks to Tiananmen Square, filling the morgues with the broken bodies of young fighters for democracy and casting a repressive nightfall across the country.   Now a dawn of sorts has gradually broken across China.

nytimes_articles.headline: Master of the Fastest Course
nytimes_articles.abstract: Roger Penske used an allusion to a 3-iron to illustrate a point about a driver today.   The golf club alluded to belongs to Bernhard Langer. The driver is Emerson Fittipaldi, who on Sunday called upon more than two decades of racing experience to give Penske's team its ninth Indianapolis 500 victory in the last 25 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Courts Plan Seeks to Add Appeals Unit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Concerned by critical backlogs in appeals court cases coming from most of New York City and its suburbs, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are seeking to expand New York State's appellate court system.   Legislative aides say leaders of the Democratic-controlled Assembly and Republican-controlled State Senate will introduce, possibly this week, proposed amendments to the State Constitution that would authorize the first major change in the appellate courts in a century. The change would add a fifth department to the four that now form the Appellate Division, the state's intermediate appeals court and the last stop for most cases.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Medical Technology Could Do You Harm; Health Savings Account
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Health Care's Fever: Not So High to Some" (The Week in Review, May 16) mentions a 1970's Rand Corporation study showing that families randomly assigned to a plan requiring them to absorb the first $1,000 a year of medical costs spent 40 percent less on their care, with "negligible" effects on health. You used this to prove that overuse is a major problem in the cost of medical care. This plan is also an easy, sensible way to solve our health care cost problem.

nytimes_articles.headline: Operators of Nuclear Plants Are Warned of a Safety Risk
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned the operators of 34 nuclear reactors around the country that the instruments they use to measure the level of water in the reactors could give a false reading during routine shutdowns and fail to detect important leaks.    The warning was issued Friday. The problem was first brought to light by an engineer at Northeast Utilities in Connecticut, who said later that he had been harassed for raising safety questions. Earlier this month, the commission agreed with him and said it would fine the utility; Northeast is appealing the ruling.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ban Keeps Day From Belmont
nytimes_articles.abstract: In an unusual move by a jockey, Pat Day decided yesterday not to appeal a five-day suspension for careless riding but to accept the penalty and thereby forego his ride on the highly regarded Cherokee Run in next Saturday's $500,000 Belmont Stakes.   "I feel very strongly about the suspension process," the 39-year-old rider said from Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. "And the decision had to be something I could live with."

nytimes_articles.headline: Never-to-Be Wedding Brings Tears at Funeral
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dressed as bride and groom, Hema Sakhrani and Shaleen Wadhwani were mourned yesterday as they lay a few feet from each other in a funeral parlor in Queens. She wore a red sari with gold trim that her uncle had brought from Bombay. He wore a bejeweled turban and a black suit. An orange sash, a symbol of the bond between man and woman in Hindu marriage rites, joined the two coffins.   Their parents held two services for the young couple, whose lives had seemed so promising until a man who the police said was obsessed with Miss Sakhrani gunned down Mr. Wadhwani last Wednesday. She was so overcome by grief that she killed herself two days later.

nytimes_articles.headline: Swarthmore Confers Degrees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Swarthmore College conferred 316 bachelor's degrees yesterday in its 121st commencement.   In ceremonies in Scott Outdoor Auditorium on the Swarthmore, Pa., campus, the college awarded honorary degrees to Dr. Arlie Hochschild, an author and professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley; Senator Harris Wofford, Democrat of Pennsylvania; Bernice Johnson Reagon, a founder of the musical group Sweet Honey in the Rock; Dr. Jonathan Fine, founder of Physicians for Human Rights, and the Rev. Jon Sobrino, professor of philosophy and theology at Jose Simeon Canas University in El Salvador.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marijuana Medication
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ashes from a fourth-century tomb near Jerusalem suggest that marijuana may have been used in the ancient Middle East to help in childbirth, a group of Israeli researchers says.   The tomb contained the skeletal remains of a teen-age girl with a full-term fetus within the pelvic area. She apparently died while giving birth or while she was in the last stages of pregnancy.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cambodian Vote Questioned   With returns showing the royalist opposition running neck and neck with the ruling party, the Government said there had been "irregularities" in last week's election. SportsTuesday, page B7.

nytimes_articles.headline: Drama in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Homo Alone Lost in Colorado  St. Marks Studio Theater 94 St. Marks Place, at First Avenue East Village Written and performed by Walter Barnett, Kelley Brower, Nora Burns, Chrisanne Eastwood, Terrence Michael and Eric Rockwell. Directed by Ms. Eastwood; lighting by Deborah Malkin; original music by Eric Rockwell; choreography by Mr. Rockwell; produced by Michael Hyman and Planet Q; associate producer, Ethan Ciment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pressure on Bentsen Mounts as Senate Faces Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen vigorously thrust himself onto center stage of the budget battle last week, lining up a majority of House Democrats from Texas for President Clinton's economic plan, buttonholing and cajoling pivotal senators, tearing into opponents at a news conference and giving loads of advice to the White House.   Probably the best proof that he was in the thick of things was the photograph taken in the Oval Office last Thursday night: a beaming Mr. Bentsen stood between President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore as they telephoned Speaker Thomas S. Foley after the House approved the plan by a margin of six votes.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Knicks Just Needed to Reach for It
nytimes_articles.abstract: A window opened in the fourth quarter for the Knicks yesterday, and when they looked inside, there was Michael Jordan tied to a chair, ready to have his house burgled for just about all that was in it.   The prize the Knicks had come to get -- one victory to take back to Madison Square Garden for a series-clinching bash tomorrow night -- was on a mantel in Jordan's living room, ready to be had. As it turned out, the Knicks had 3 minutes 4 seconds to steal Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals. They could not. They wilted badly in the heat of going for the big score and were beaten by the Bulls, 105-95. They went home to face the trial of their lives, knowing if they should happen to lose Game 5, the window at Jordan's house may not open again.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plan Limits Development In Lincoln Center Area
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Planning Department will propose zoning changes today that would put new restrictions on commercial development and building heights in the area around Lincoln Center.   Besides restricting the height of new buildings, the new use and design requirements for the Lincoln Square special zoning district are intended to limit vehicular and pedestrian traffic in an area that has seen the addition of 18 new buildings since 1969.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: What Matters to America. Regarding "Reasons Not to Make Too Much of Clinton's Early Poll Results" (Opinion, May 14) by Kevin Phillips:. As I read the 10 reasons not to worry about Bill Clinton's poor approval ratings, I was reminded of why I vot

nytimes_articles.headline: Kukoc Passes Bulls' Physical
nytimes_articles.abstract: Toni Kukoc, the Croatian star who is considered to be the best basketball player in Europe, has completed physical examinations given by the Bulls, Jerry Krause, the team's director of operations, said today.   Krause said that Kukoc, who was in Chicago during the holiday weekend but did not attend either Bulls-Knicks game, must now make a final decision on getting out of his contract with Benetton Treviso of the Italian league within a couple of weeks. That would enable the 6-foot-10-inch Kukoc to negotiate a deal with the Bulls beginning July 1.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Closer Brothers Than the Jameses
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your May 22 Chronicle item about the American Academy of Arts and Letters falsifies what was said at the recent annual meeting about William James's reason for declining membership. He did not say "he would never join anything that included his younger brother, Henry."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Running the Full Gamut Of Balanchine's Ballet
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Liebeslieder Walzer," which the New York City Ballet will perform tonight at the New York State Theater, and "Raymonda Variations," which is scheduled for Friday, symbolize the two poles of the company's continuing "Balanchine Celebration."   "Raymonda Variations" (1961) is typical of George Balanchine's work -- a plotless suite of solos and ensembles in which he reiterates his allegiance to ballet's 350-year-old classical vocabulary, especially as it had been modernized, in his view, by the 19th-century choreographer Marius Petipa. Balanchine's own brand of 20th-century neo-classicism is evident in his reworking of classical technique in this sparkling gem of a ballet. But it is also a work in which he pays overt homage to Petipa by quoting directly from that choreographer's 1898 ballet, "Raymonda," set to Glazounov's music.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Need of Public Support, Doctors Try Image Transplant
nytimes_articles.abstract: For Dr. Michael Elia, a Westchester orthopedic surgeon, the national debate over health care has come to this: he has taken the M.D. license plates off his sports car.   "People see you driving around in a little convertible with M.D. plates and they get hostile," said Dr. Elia, who practices at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. "It's just a $14,000 Miata, but people see the plates and assume its a $60,000 Porsche. There's such resentment against doctors; why make it worse?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Murder Suspect Is Returned
nytimes_articles.abstract: A sanitation inspector accused of killing a 4-year-old boy and stuffing his body into a trash compactor in Brooklyn was returned to New York City yesterday after he was arrested on a Texas highway on Saturday, the police said. The suspect, Stephan David Poole, was taken to Brooklyn Central Booking to await arraignment on second-degree murder charges, probably this morning, a police spokesman said. Mr. Poole, 31, had evaded the police since May 20, when the body of the boy, Kayesean Blackledge, was found in the Linden Houses Housing project. Mr. Poole had skipped around various places in Florida, Mississippi and Texas before he was pulled over in Huntsville, Tex., Saturday afternoon.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: JEWELL JACKSON McCABE, the founder and chairwoman of the National Coalition of 100 Black Women, has been elected to the board of trustees of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.    Ms. McCabe, a leader in numerous civil rights and women's rights causes, is also on the board of overseers for the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bosnians' Dream World. We Bosnians are coming to the terrible conclusion that it is illusory to think we are a part of Europe and that the world community stands for human rights and justice.. The West values the lives of a few hundred of its soldiers, wh

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; From Italy to Balanchine, via Petipa
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Ballet's performance on Saturday afternoon of George Balanchine's "Harlequinade," one of the major revivals of the Balanchine Celebration, may well prove to be one of the happiest and best-danced performances in the festival.   There will never be another Balanchine, nor another Edward Villella and Patricia McBride, the original Harlequin and Columbine in the production. Nor should there be. But both the revival and the cast that danced it, nine years after its last performance at City Ballet, managed not only to stir potent memories among the balletomanes in the audience but also to make the ballet a fresh experience.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Recital and a Debut Merge, to a Degree
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christopher Creaghan, an organist from Canada studying at the Manhattan School, was faced with a degree-requirement recital and a New York debut wrapped into one on Wednesday night at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. He handled the experience with poise. Mr. Creaghan's program stretched as wide as it knew how over the repertory, often favoring excerpts from a variety of pieces rather than concentrated doses of one or two styles. While some recitals serve particular musical needs, this one was clearly designed to show what one organist could do.   The first half was principally Baroque, offering, among pieces by Sweelinck and Grigny, Bach's C-major Trio Sonata: chaste and cheerful outer movements, an austere Largo in between. The second half tended toward bigger, later works and ended with Messiaen's familiar "Nativite du Seigneur," in which Mr. Creaghan nicely exploited the size of this church and the power of its organ.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spain: Reawakened Voters Watch the Hair Cream Fly
nytimes_articles.abstract: - Politics is again a fashionable topic in Spain. This may seem unsurprising with general elections due on Sunday, but after 10 years in which each election meant a preordained Socialist Party victory, much of the excitement had disappeared from the process.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; The Constant Hearts
nytimes_articles.abstract: The decision to pick a public relations man for three Republican Presidencies as the spokesman for the new Democratic Administration is an important step meaning one or more of the following things:   1. The public and press are just as stupid as President Clinton obviously thinks they are and have never seen a cynical political gimmick they would not buy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miles From Anywhere, Flocks of Tourists Descend
nytimes_articles.abstract: The tour buses are already crawling past the Elvis-A-Rama, the funnel cake parlors, hillbilly moccasin emporiums and glitzy new music theaters here in America's fastest-growing vacation center.   Once a sleepy Ozarks town, but now a billion-dollar phenomenon, Branson has become more than a refuge for a bewildering array of aging pop stars and pre-Garth Brooks country musicians who thrill the faithful at more than 30 theaters here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A front-page news analysis article yesterday about President Clinton's appointment of a new communications director rendered the name of a top adviser to President John F. Kennedy incorrectly in some editions. He is Theodore C. Sorensen.

nytimes_articles.headline: Limits Seen On Human Existence
nytimes_articles.abstract: IS it possible, using statistics alone, to predict how long space exploration, the Catholic Church, the Miss America contest, the human race or the universe as a whole will continue to exist? A Princeton University astrophysicist has concluded that these and many other predictions are not only possible, but can be made with 95 percent reliability.   As he described his hypothesis in the current issue of the British journal Nature, the scientist, Dr. J. Richard Gott 3d, proposed that the longevity of things can be estimated remarkably well from their histories. All that is needed to calculate roughly how long something is likely to last is to assume that there is nothing special about it -- nothing to particularly distinguish it from all the other objects or systems or creatures or intervals of time in its class. Theorists call this assumption the "Copernican principle," referring to the Polish astronomer Copernicus, who concluded that the Earth was not at the center of the solar system (or universe), and therefore did not occupy any "special" place.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Medical Technology Could Do You Harm; A Dream of an H.M.O.
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Let Us Journey Into the Mind of Managed Care" (letters, May 16): Let me guide you on another journey, into a health maintenance organization, with my 17-year practice experience as the guide.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q&A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Keeping Your Balance   Q.  How can people stand erect if the stomach weighs more than the feet?   A.  People are indeed top-heavy, and balance, the ability to stand upright and move around without falling over, is not as simple as it feels. It requires constant tiny adjustment of muscles as the weight shifts on the feet, much as a juggler maneuvers to balance a plate on a stick.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Limits of Tame and Wild at the Zoo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Among the big scenes in "Zoo" are the stillbirth of a rhinoceros, the egg-laying of a crocodile, the tooth-cleaning of a gorilla and the hunt for a pit bull who killed some deer. But Frederick Wiseman is not the sort of documentary maker who settles for big scenes. In this, his 25th work, as in his other studies of American institutions, from a hospital to a race track to Central Park, he allows his subject to reveal itself, the mundane along with the sensational.   What that means for tomorrow night's two-hour visit to the Miami Metrozoo are many pictures of fauna on both sides of the bars. The zoo workers are efficient and conscientious, the visiting children are cute and the elephants, chimpanzees, zebras and so forth are easy to look at, even if you think you recognize most of them from other public television programs. But they do not make for steadily enthralling television. The opening 10 minutes of disporting families and showoff animals tests even a Wiseman fan's endurance, and after the sixth or seventh time the zoo train goes by, you might find yourself hoping for a derailment.

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. Showdown on Gay Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shhhh. The Republicans who control the New York State Senate prefer not to talk in public about the gay-rights legislation pending before their chamber. With the Legislature scheduled to adjourn at the end of the month, there's a real danger that G.O.P. senators will kill the gay-rights bill without so much as one word of public debate.   If that happens, the Senate majority leader, Ralph Marino, will have to answer not only for defeat of a worthy civil rights initiative, but for the sad capitulation of his once-proud state party to intolerant extremists.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International 2-9  REPRESSION EASING IN CHINA  Nearly four years after the brutal suppression of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing, repression persists in China but seems to be easing.  A1  DOWNSIZING A STRONGMAN  Life President Hastings Kamuzu Banda of Malawi has long occupied his own quirky niche: part African, part Victorian, part Mussolini, part Monty Python. Now his hold on the country is being challenged.  A1

nytimes_articles.headline: Lights, Camera, Cup? Gretzky Is Ready
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the first four years of the Wayne Gretzky era, the Los Angeles Kings were the fool's gold of hockey, one of those California dreams. Gretzky gave them glitter and helped sell tickets and jerseys, but they never really mined a mother lode.   With his sublime skills receding but still considerable, Gretzky was like a colonial missionary from hockey's old world. To the uninitiated, in the heat and dust of the American Southwest, he preached the coming glory of his sport, spreading the message to an ambivalent entertainment capital. To the converted of the old cities, he urged repentance and reform. Abandon fighting, he said, and market the business beyond the devoted cult that has sustained it for so long.

nytimes_articles.headline: Big Noise About Sound and Motion
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE annual Spring Comdex computer exposition in Atlanta last week was much noisier than ever before, a result of the (Boom! Flash!) explosion of multimedia hardware and software.    Multimedia is the term loosely applied to any computer product that can produce CD-quality stereo sound, voice reproduction, full-motion video or animation on screen and high-resolution color graphics. Eventually all personal computers will have these abilities, but for the time being multimedia is considered special enough to warrant its own category.

nytimes_articles.headline: Image of Old Hoboken Recorded by an Invader
nytimes_articles.abstract: NORA JACOBSON began shooting Hoboken about the time landlords here started throwing tenants out.   It was 1984. The old port city was going condo.

nytimes_articles.headline: China Makes Population Control an Ism
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "China is a very big country with a very big problem: it has 7 percent of the earth's arable land -- and more than 20 percent of all its people. Today they number 1.17 billion. In several decades they will probably number 1.9 billion." Thus begins "China's Cruelty and Women's Rights" (editorial, May 21).

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemalan Leader Is Pressed to Yield Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: The opposition to President Jorge Serrano Elias's seizure of almost dictatorial powers grew more defiant today as the Government's isolation increased.    One day after military leaders backed away from their support for the President, prominent citizens called for his resignation, small groups of protesters again challenged a ban on public assembly, and newspapers began to openly mock the standing censorship of the press.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   BOSTON RED SOX -- Activated Jose Melendez, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Placed Jeff Richardson, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Optioned Ken Ryan, pitcher, to Pawtucket of the International League. Recalled Jim Byrd, infielder, from Pawtucket.   MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Activated Angel Miranda, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Sent Josias Manzanillo, pitcher, to New Orleans of the American Association.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia's Elite Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "At Elite Russian School, O Is for Openness," your excellent May 24 front-page article, omits one vital point. How did the few lucky children get into the school? "About 170 children applied this year for the lowest grades," you state, "and only 70 were accepted." Was it on merit? Yes, but not only.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Recognize Macedonia Now . Your editorial, "Recognize Macedonia" (May 26) is wise and timely. Failure to do so would encourage the power-hungry Serbs to start another bloody adventure. It is time President Bill Clinton took a firm stand and demon

nytimes_articles.headline: Despite Heat, Christopher Has 'the Time of My Life'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher says he's never been happier.   "Everyone who knows me well knows I'm having the time of my life," the 67-year-old lawyer said over lunch on Friday. "They're struck by how happy I seem to be in the job."

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Can Germany Be Trusted?. Regarding "For East and West, East Europeans Need Security" (Opinion, May 3) by William Pfaff:. Mr. Pfaff speaks of "rising pressures inside Germany to challenge existing borders" in the East. This is news to m

nytimes_articles.headline: Animals That Are Peerless Athletes
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO the recreational joggers of the world, champion runners like Carl Lewis and Olga Markova are the anointed children of Zeus, cardiovascular demigods who seem to ignite the air molecules around them as they race.    Yet even the most elite human athlete is thoroughly pathetic compared with nature's other aerobic masters. Take the pronghorn antelope of Wyoming, for example, a goat-sized ungulate that may rank as the greatest athlete alive. Its maximum speed of 60 miles per hour is second only to the cheetah's top pace of 70 m.p.h. But while the cheetah can sprint for just a few seconds before practically collapsing, the pronghorn can maintain its freeway stride for an hour.

nytimes_articles.headline: Forsaken Frontier: Revisiting the Oregon Trail -- Last of three articles.; 150 Years Later, Indians Bitterly Cope With Results of Whites' Arrival
nytimes_articles.abstract: The map of the American West in the first big year of the Oregon Trail showed a sea of open space, and carried warnings about the people who were living on much of it. The Pawnee, Cheyenne, Arapaho, Sioux, Shoshone, Crow, Nez Perce, Ute, Spokane, Cayuse, Chinook, Umpqua -- these tribes were as prominent as any landmark on the migrants' guide of 1843.   Moving west along the old Oregon Trail today, a traveler who wanders off the interstate can still find the American Indian bands that both sustained and threatened the wagon trains. The people live inside straight lines on the map, nations within a nation. They are mostly off the road and out of sight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Robbery Suspect Is Killed
nytimes_articles.abstract: A robbery suspect was shot and killed by the police early yesterday when he drew a gun during a foot chase through backyards in Cambria Heights, Queens, the police said. They said a second suspect escaped. The dead man was identified by the police as Ian Johnson, 21, of 138-75 Francis Lewis Boulevard, said Lieut. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman. Lieutenant O'Donnell said Sgt. Donald Burton and Officer Riccardo Osuna of the 105th Precinct were chasing two men suspected of robbing a woman of $60 at 6 A.M. on Linden Boulevard. The officers fired at Mr. Johnson after he pulled his gun, Lieutenant O'Donnell said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perkins Wakes Up and Smells a Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Seattle is an espresso town, which may be why Sam Perkins has finally awakened.   Predictably nicknamed "Sleepy," because he always walks around as if it's 4 A.M., Perkins has turned into the SuperSonics' ambulance driver. Whenever the team has needed a pick-me-up in the Western Conference finals, it has been Perkins dead-aiming a 3-point shot or Perkins backing in for an unobstructable hook. Sonic fans, without his permission, have begun the following battle cry: "Sam, I Am."

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Organ; The Art of Improvisation
nytimes_articles.abstract: McNeil Robinson is one of increasingly few organists who maintain the art of improvisation. Last Tuesday night at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at a moment's notice, Mr. Robinson conjured up a "symphony in four movements" based on themes submitted by Ned Rorem. Each movement found an effective dramatic shape, expertly deploying Mr. Rorem's fluid and engaging material. Especially impressive was the second movement, an Andante, in which a lilting melody stretched out to fill a space of considerable breadth.   The remainder of the program was taken up by a broad selection of works from different eras: Marcel Dupre's "Sept Pieces," three anonymous 17th-century pieces and Beavarlet-Charpentier's Fugue in A Minor, Bach's Prelude and Fugue in D (B.W.V. 532) and Franck's Choral No. 2. While Mr. Robinson is not perhaps the most agile of players, he has a strong grasp of tension and release; the Dupre rang out with particular force and clarity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Derrick Thomas Recalls His Father at Memorial
nytimes_articles.abstract: DERRICK THOMAS, the Kansas City Chiefs' All-Pro linebacker, said yesterday that he just wanted to live up to the courage of the father he never knew, a co-pilot who was killed during the Vietnam War.   "It's very ironic that my father's last mission was named Linebacker 2," said Thomas, who was among the speakers who joined PRESIDENT CLINTON at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. "It's very ironic that in college I had 52 sacks and my father flew a B-52."

nytimes_articles.headline: How New York City Confronts the Problem of TB in Its Jails
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Where Tuberculosis Breeds" (editorial, May 11) identifies the reasons tuberculosis is a serious public health problem in the New York City criminal justice system. Unfortunately, you gloss over the Dinkins administration's response.

nytimes_articles.headline: Scanner Pinpoints Sites of Thought as People See or Speak
nytimes_articles.abstract: USING souped up versions of conventional brain imaging machines, scientists can now peer into the workings of the human brain, making movies of changes that occur as the mind thinks, talks, listens, dreams and imagines.    At the handful of centers where the technique is being developed, researchers are borrowing the machines at night and on weekends when patients do not need them and, like children in a toy store, are exploring one another's brains with unbridled glee. In recent months they have made movies of the brain's circuitry as it performs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marian Anderson Tribute
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Remembering Marian Anderson," a tribute to the contralto, will take place at Carnegie Hall next Monday at 11 A.M. Isaac Stern and James DePreist, the music director of the Oregon Symphony Orchestra and Miss Anderson's nephew, will offer reminiscences, and recordings by Miss Anderson will be played. Admission is free. Tickets are available at the Carnegie Hall box office, 154 West 57th Street. Miss Anderson died on April 8 at age 96.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: GOLF  Victory for Langer    The Masters champion, Bernhard Langer, eagled the 12th hole for a second consecutive day and fired a six-under-par 68 as he breezed to a six-shot victory in the $1 million European PGA Championship in Virginia Water, England. (AP)   COLLEGE BASEBALL    Longhorns in Series    Mark Prather singled home the winning run as Texas rallied for two runs in the ninth inning and beat Southern Cal, 3-2, yesterday in Austin, Tex., to advance to the College World Series for the 27th time. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1918: New Submarines

nytimes_articles.headline: Longtime African Dictator's Grip Loosening
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the pantheon of Africa's Big Men, Life President Hastings Kamuzu Banda of Malawi has long occupied his own quirky niche: part African, part Victorian, part Mussolini, part Monty Python.   To casual travelers in Africa, Dr. Banda is the homburg-hatted disciplinarian who to this day forbids bell-bottom pants and over-the-collar hair for men as signs of moral decadence. His Government banned the Simon and Garfunkel song "Cecilia" as offensive to the woman the unmarried President's official hostess, Cecilia Tamanda Kadzamira.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Made for a Mile,' Ibero Sizzles in the Metropolitan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ibero, the 6-year-old war horse from Argentina and California, outran one of New York's most glittering fields of thoroughbreds yesterday to win the 100th Metropolitan Handicap in a sizzling performance that could influence honors and, even, careers.   He won it after a dramatic duel down the homestretch that gave all nine horses in the race a shot. And he won it by running down the Canadian star Alydeed and his fellow California traveler Bertrando in the final 200 yards.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; Tonsorialitis
nytimes_articles.abstract: No, I'm not sore about the President taking his business to another tonsorial artist. If he thinks Cristophe of Beverly Hills can give him a better trim than Lary of Little Rock, O.K., he's the President, it's his hair, more power to him.   That's Lary with only one "r," please. It used to have two, but my bride said "Larry" looked overstuffed with alphabet. I said to her what did she mean "overstuffed with alphabet," and she said it just looked too old-fashioned.

nytimes_articles.headline: Effective Publicity Examples On a Disk
nytimes_articles.abstract: A BUSINESS thrives on publicity -- good publicity -- but not every one knows how to get it. The owner of a small business may serve as public relations person or may assign the duties to a subordinate who learns, or fails to learn, on the job. A medium-size to large business may have its own person, or staff, to handle publicity or may hire an outside agency.   Publicity Builder, a book-software combination from Jian, formerly Tools for Sales, of Los Altos, Calif., amounts to a course in how to win editors and influence reporters. Every public relations person could benefit from the wisdom of admonitions like these:

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hypermodernism is old in the annals of military combat but a latecomer to chess. While its strategy of provoking opponents to overreach themselves and then surround and destroy their frailly supported, advanced units did not become a self-conscious approach to the chess openings until the rise of players like Richard Reti, Gyula Breyer and Aron Nimzovich in the 1920's, this had been stock in trade to the Spartan infantry at least as early as the Persian Wars in the Fifth Century B.C.   Its lure in chess is the spirit of adventure that accompanies a bold plan. What if the opponent's thrust becomes a juggernaut? You are crushed. But what satisfaction there is in undermining the enemy outposts and pouring through the gaps to victory. This was the reward that the Armenian grandmaster Rafael Vaganian earned for his game with the Dutch grandmaster John Van der Wiel from Round 1 of the Sixth Klooster Tournament in Ter Apel, the Netherlands, in early April. Vaganian tie for first place with the Russian grandmaster Aleksandr Khalifman, each having scored 3 1/2-1 1/2.

nytimes_articles.headline: Janet Reno's Independent Stand
nytimes_articles.abstract: Among recent Attorneys General, Janet Reno stands alone in support of the Federal independent counsel law, calling for a court-appointed prosecutor for investigations of high executive branch officials. The distinction does her credit.    The law, first enacted in 1978 with Watergate freshly in mind, lapsed last year but President Clinton is pledged to revive it. It takes cases involving Cabinet secretaries and a few dozen other top officials away from the Attorney General and gives them to an outside prosecutor who can't be fired except for good cause.

nytimes_articles.headline: Germany Arrests Young Suspect In Bombing That Killed 5 Turks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The German police had a young man in custody on murder and arson charges today in connection with a firebombing that killed five Turks in Solingen on Saturday.   The arrest did not stem the violence that has shaken Solingen over the last three days. Thousands of people marched peacefully through the streets to show their sorrow, but small groups protesting the killings smashed store windows, looted and clashed with the police. One group temporarily blocked roads leading to the Cologne-Bonn airport, forcing the cancellation of several flights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mayor Race Focuses on Word
nytimes_articles.abstract: A dispute over the use of the word "pogrom" has once again focused the New York City mayoral race on the 1991 disturbances in Crown Heights.   The dispute began on Sunday in a television interview when Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, called the three days in which unruly mobs of black youths assaulted Jews a "pogrom." The word, which dictionaries say means an "organized massacre," is variously defined as often officially "condoned," "prompted" or "encouraged."

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; The Way Universities Profit by War Research
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Cold War and American Science  The Military-Industrial-Academic Complex at M.I.T. and Stanford  By Stuart W. Leslie  Illustrated. 332 pages. Columbia University Press. $42.   In "The Cold War and American Science," Stuart W. Leslie, a professor in the department of the history of science at Johns Hopkins University, takes off from the theme of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's only memorable phrase: his warning against the unwarranted influence of "the military-industrial complex." Mr. Eisenhower used the words in his farewell address on Jan. 17, 1961, just before leaving the White House, but its significance echoes to the present time of big-power peace.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: There are walks to raise money for breast cancer and walks to raise awareness of AIDS, walks for civil rights and walks for political causes. On Saturday, there will be a "Walk for Water," intended to help protect New York City's and Westchester County's water supply.    Sponsored by Riverkeeper, a Westchester organization that monitors the watershed of the Hudson River, and the Open Space Institute, a land conservation organization, a group of celebrities led by ROBERT F. KENNEDY Jr.  will take an eight-mile hike around the Croton Reservoir. It will end with a picnic and concert at Croton Gorge Park.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report in the Benefits column of Styles of the Times on Sunday about a dinner being held this evening to benefit CASA, a drug education organization, misstated the location. It is the Pierre Hotel, not the Plaza. The report also rendered the organization's full name incorrectly. It is the Center on Addiction and Drug Abuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Riter, One-on-One, Makes Orange No.1
nytimes_articles.abstract: The game and the national championship came down to a one-on-one battle right in front of the goal: Gary Lehrman, the North Carolina goalkeeper, versus Matt Riter, Syracuse's leading scorer.   Riter had had a quiet tournament, but he slammed the ball past the frozen Lehrman. The remaining 8 seconds ticked away and Syracuse had won the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I championship, 13-12, in a match in which the score was tied seven times.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: One of the most exciting finishes in the 65-year history of the Goldman Pairs took place Sunday night at the Sheraton New York Hotel in Manhattan. With one two-board round remaining, the defending champions, Steve Becker of Cos Cob, Conn., and Richard de Martino of Riverside, Conn., seemed to have a good chance of repeating. They were in second place, 8 match points behind Dale Beers of Springfield, Pa., and Jim Gingrich of Lansdale, Pa. Three other pairs were in contention.  Sadly, Becker and de Martino were knocked out of the running by a 25-point technical penalty for a misduplication at the start of the session. But there was still a Becker winner, though unrelated: R. Jay Becker and Ira Herman, both of Manhattan, surged from fifth to first to take the title. In two boards they scored 44 points out of a possible 50, and ended two and a half points ahead of Beers and Gingrich. Yesterday, Becker and Herman began their defense of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, hoping for a rare double.

nytimes_articles.headline: Courier Cracks Mirror Image at French
nytimes_articles.abstract: Coping with Thomas Muster center-stage on the French Open clay is a little like going one on one in the weight room with Arnold Schwarzenegger. But today Jim Courier, the two-time defending champion, handled his fourth-round assignment, held over from Sunday because of stormy weather, without a quaver.   After all, at the French Open, Courier has been transformed into a muscle man who has yet to meet his match, and he upped his Paris winning streak to 18 matches in a row by out-blustering Muster, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Grim Reaper Cuts Down The Knicks
nytimes_articles.abstract: THIS is what comes from a "grimmer, darker" mood. Michael Jordan comes out in a glowering rage and punishes the Knicks for all the indignities he has suffered.   Jordan administered this treatment yesterday, like the dean of boys in a hard-core high school back in the days of corporal punishment. He flailed away at the Knicks, in heated dispassion, looking for every sore spot.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Haven's Task: Tying City to Region To Promote Growth
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three decades ago, when Lyndon B. Johnson came into office with an ambitious urban agenda, this small New England city was an exciting laboratory for change, a model of urban renewal and a testing ground for the war on poverty.   Today New Haven is a city of disappointments and diminished hopes. The laboratory is long closed and cluttered with its failures: misshapen renewal projects that haunt downtown, and the unchecked spread of poverty through neighborhoods.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nuclear Peace for Pyongyang?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Will North Korea try to build nuclear weapons or not? That will be the central issue when Pyongyang's First Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs meets with State Department officials in New York tomorrow..   North Korea raised fears about its intentions in March by denying international inspectors access to its nuclear sites and threatening to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. It needs to allay those fears now -- by remaining a signatory of the treaty and granting access to all its nuclear sites.

nytimes_articles.headline: Drama in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Master and Margarita, or, The Devil Comes to Moscow  Theater for the New City 155 First Avenue, at 10th Street East Village Through June 13 By Mikhail Bulgakov; directed by David Willinger; intepreted for the theater by Jean-Claude van Itallie; set design, Mark Symczak; lighting design, Tommy Barker; costume design, Tanya Serdiuk; music, Arthur Abrams; masks and special props, Hjordis Linn. Presented by the Theater for the New City, George Bartenieff, executive director; Crystal Field, executive artistic director, and Play Producers, Annette Moskowitz and Alexander Racolin.  WITH: Eran Bohem, Jonathan Teague Cook, Gary Kimble, Lisa Nicholas and Kolawole Ogundiran.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mets Hail The Victor On Return From Exile
nytimes_articles.abstract: The wind was up at Wrigley Field. The score was 6-4, the game only in the sixth inning. Men were on base. The Mets' manager was on the mound. Disaster was in the air for New York, and the baseball was put in Paul Gibson's left hand.   Boom. Dwight Smith turned on Gibson's third pitch, and the ball landed in the ivy, inches below the screen that would have claimed it as a home run. Now, the score was 6-5. There were Cubs on second and third, and there was still one out. The flashbacks were unnerving Gibson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perot's Organization Shows Fissures and Sagging Morale
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ross Perot's grass-roots political organization is in turmoil, riven by disputes that are beginning to cost it some of its most-committed volunteers.   Mr. Perot's personal popularity has never been higher, but morale in his organization, United We Stand America, is beginning to sag.

nytimes_articles.abstract: "I ask you, at this monument, can any American be out of place? And can any Commander in Chief be in any other place but here on this day?" -- PRESIDENT CLINTON, at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.  [ A14:4. ]

nytimes_articles.abstract: Chernobyl and Bhopal. In his review of "Ablaze" by Piers Paul Read (Books, May 11), Dan Kurzman writes that the nuclear plant disaster at Chernobyl "became a symbol of the whole rotting Communist system" and then, without a blink, ment

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Colon, Call Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: The allegation that City Councilman Rafael Castaneira Colon doesn't live in his own district is under investigation by the Council and the Bronx District Attorney. Mr. Colon may be exonerated. But if authorities find that he has been thumbing his nose at his South Bronx constituents, the Council leadership will have an obligation to punish him harshly as a signal to Council members about their responsibility to constituents. It is the Council's fundamental job, after all, to give communities a voice in City Hall.   According to a girlfriend who has accused Mr. Colon of assault, he has falsely claimed her address as his for years. A Council member can, for the term ending this year only, live anywhere in the city; because of redistricting in 1991, a court temporarily lifted the residency requirement. But it's a criminal violation for elected officials to lie on official documents about their residences. If Mr. Colon is found to have violated a law, the Council would have several options, from reprimanding him to expelling him. So far, Speaker Peter Vallone, who firmly controls the Council, has sent mixed signals. Every elected official, he said, "has the moral and legal obligation to live and to serve in the district he or she represents." But Mr. Vallone also said, "If any elected official is failing to adequately serve his or her constituency, there is no better place to remedy that concern than at the voting booth."

nytimes_articles.headline: Hohenau Journal; Sure, Mengele Was at Home Here, but Bormann?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Using the early morning light to help her fading vision, Michline Reynaers sat recently in a sunny corner of the Hotel Tirol here, knitting socks for a grandchild.   "Everyone in town talked about how well he played the piano," the 72-year-old hotel keeper recalled, speaking in German of the courteous, mustachioed visitor who patronized her restaurant in 1959. "I was introduced to him as Mr. Mengele."

nytimes_articles.headline: Cyclist Hit Twice and Dragged By Drunken Driver, Police Say
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 29-year-old man was knocked off his bicycle by a drunken driver in upper Manhattan on Sunday night, and as he limped to his feet, he was struck a second time by the same car and dragged for eight blocks, the police and witnesses said.   The man, Christopher Donohue, a school custodian, was in critical but stable condition at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center last night. He suffered internal injuries and third-degree friction burns to his face and body, and he lost his left ear, his doctor, M. Kamel Abouzahr, said last night.

nytimes_articles.headline: Koreas: Menace, Uncertainty and a Ray of Hope
nytimes_articles.abstract: - The crisis that looms over the Korean Peninsula - the worst since the armistice was signed nearly 40 years ago - might be quickly resolved were the United Nations not so bogged down in Cambodia and ex-Yugoslavia. The Security Council and political leaders in America and Europe have had little time to study reports of large troop movements in North Korea, where the self-styled Great Leader, Kim Il Sung, 81, faces increasing opposition to his efforts to ensure that his son, Kim Jong Il, 51, will assume power when the elder man departs.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Few Players Missing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of pro league commitments, several top American players will be missing when the United States plays Brazil in the first match of the U.S. Cup '93 on Sunday at New Haven.   The United States Soccer Federation said yesterday that it was unable to obtain the release of midfielder TAB RAMOS from Real Betis in the Spanish League, and defender THOMAS DOOLEY (FC Kaiserslautern) and forward ERIC WYNALDA (Saarbrucken) from the German Bundesliga.

nytimes_articles.headline: In an Overture to an Enemy, Libyan Pilgrims Visit Israel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly 200 Libyans arrived in Jerusalem today for a three-day visit to Muslim holy sites on the first group pilgrimage by citizens of an Arab country that is officially at war with Israel.   The visit followed a recent series of overtures to the United States and Israel from the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Israeli officials welcomed the pilgrims but disagreed about the political significance of the visit from a country long considered one of Israel's most implacable foes.

nytimes_articles.headline: What they're reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Pakenham, British ambassador to Luxembourg, is reading "Seeds of Change: Five Plants that Transformed Mankind" by Henry Hobhouse.. "It's a fascinating book. Each chapter is devoted to sugar, cotton, tea, or quinine, which allowed wh

nytimes_articles.headline: Evidence for Planet X Evaporates in Spotlight of New Research
nytimes_articles.abstract: ASTRONOMERS can quit looking for the elusive "Planet X" because it is not there, a new study of solar system measurements has concluded.   For a half century stargazers have hunted for Planet X, the solar system's hypothetical 10th planet. Its existence was inferred from what appeared to be irregularities in the orbital motions of several known planets. But a new study of the outer planets indicates that the long chase, based on presumed wobbles in the orbits of Uranus and Neptune caused by a planet, was based on erroneous observations and calculations.

nytimes_articles.headline: All Jordan, All Even: Chicago Takes Game 4
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was spectacular, but from Michael Jordan, the spectacular is never unexpected. Jordan was due for a performance like this, a brilliant 54-point barrage that lifted the Chicago Bulls, deflated the Knicks and dramatically changed the atmosphere of a series that New York no longer controls.   Carrying his team with a remarkable long-range shooting exhibition, Jordan led the Bulls to a series-tying 105-95 victory this afternoon at Chicago Stadium in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals. The four-of-seven-game series is tied, 2-2, heading into a crucial Game 5 confrontation Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON CONSIDERS TAX ON HOSPITALS
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is seriously considering a new tax on hospitals to help finance medical care for people who currently have no health insurance, Administration officials said today.   The officials said the proposal would be high on the agenda when Mr. Clinton meets this week with his advisers to review the design of his plan to guarantee health care for all Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rabin Shuffles His Cabinet But Critics Aren't Appeased
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a Cabinet shuffle over the weekend, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin managed to put the most serious political crisis of his year-old Government behind him.    But today he still had to contend with criticism of his leadership and the possible implications of his leadership style for the Middle East peace talks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Make Health Reform Work. Draft Doctors.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The national debate on health care reform has highlighted a fundamental flaw in our medical system -- the lack of doctors, even for those who have insurance, in rural and inner-city areas. There is only one practical way to deliver medical care to the tens of millions of Americans who lack it: mandatory public service by physicians.

At the end of 1992, an estimated 3,700 non-specialist physicians were needed in medically underserved areas. Although many physicians provide care to the needy at a reduced fee or no charge, volunteer efforts, splendid as they are, will never reach all Americans isolated by poverty, geography or residence in inadequate nursing homes, prisons or mental institutions. While these citizens receive care for serious illnesses requiring hospitalization, they remain deprived of basic health care.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nicklaus's Travel Plans
nytimes_articles.abstract: JACK NICKLAUS says his performance in this week's Memorial Tournament will help determine whether he plays in the British Open.   Nicklaus has played in every British Open since turning pro in 1962, and he has won three. But he missed the cut in the championship last year, and he finished 44th and 63d in the two previous years. This year's British Open is July 15-18 at the Royal St. George course in England.

nytimes_articles.headline: Insects Castes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Insects may have developed a social class system at least 95 million years earlier than had been thought, say scientists who stumbled on some fossilized termite nests in Arizona.   The three nests, indications of social behavior and cooperative building, were found in a rock formation that is 220 million years old, said Stephen Hasiotis, a doctoral candidate in paleontology at the University of Colorado in Boulder.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in the Westchester Weekly section on Sunday about a directory of Jewish organizations mistated the date of a concert marking the 50th anniversary of the Hebrew Congregation of Somers. It will take place on Sunday, June 6, at 7:30 P.M. at the temple, on Mervyn Drive in Shenorock.

nytimes_articles.headline: To the Spider Woman, Broadway Is Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Chita Rivera (Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero, to be more precise) is impatient with questions about the Tony Awards on Sunday. She actually rolls her eyes and sighs when asked about whether she thinks she'll win the honors for best actress in a musical, for her title role in "Kiss of the Spider Woman."    "You delude yourself," she said on a recent afternoon at the Broadhurst Theater, in a cozy dressing room overstocked with long-stemmed red roses. "You keep telling yourself it doesn't matter, that whoever wins, that'll be just fine. Then you get there. And? It's war! If you lose, that walk out of the theater is the longest you'll ever take."

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooks Takes a Walk As Devils Jog in Place
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a disagreement with New Jersey's management over the direction the team ought to take, Herb Brooks resigned as coach yesterday after fulfilling one season of the three-year contract he was given last June 5 to "take the Devils to the next level."   Brooks, whose team (40-37-7) tied the Islanders for third place in the Patrick Division but was eliminated in five games by Pittsburgh in the first round of the playoffs, wanted the Devils to, in effect, take a step backward before going forward. The 55-year-old coach viewed youth and speed as the main ingredients for building success. Management felt the players on the team were good enough to become Stanley Cup contenders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Purity, Pederasty And a Fallen Heroine
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the morning of April 2, in the courthouse of the small northern California mining town of Jamestown, a preliminary hearing was under way on charges against Daniel Driver for allegedly molesting several young boys. During the proceedings, the mother of one of the boys, Ellie Nesler, thought she detected Mr. Driver smirking. So she went and got a gun, walked back into court and stopped the smirks forever. Now charged with murder, Ellie Nesler, cast by the law as a killer, has made herself available for the role of cultural heroine.   Ellie Nesler took us at our word. Believing that Mr. Driver was a pederast, she did what society wants done to pederasts: she plugged him five times, stopping perversion dead in its tracks.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Writer and His Tools . Regarding "Back to the Past" (Letters, May 11) from Douglas G. Turner:. Surely what one writes is more important than what one uses to write it? The computer, as a tool, is not shoddy per se, although the literature pr

nytimes_articles.headline: Today the Questions Are About the Knicks
nytimes_articles.abstract: They had created questions, serious questions, about the two-time defending champions. They had occasionally made Michael Jordan appear ordinary.   The Knicks came here with the chance to make their Eastern Conference championship series with the Chicago Bulls a short one. But when it was time for them to return to New York, escorted to the exit stairwell amid the delirious noise of Chicago Stadium, that chance had vanished and their hopes of advancing to the National Basketball Association finals were threatened.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yanks and Perez Get A Picnic on the Grass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Melido Perez is not used to this feeling. He knows what it's like to pitch with no runs in his favor. He knows what it's like to pitch out of a hole. But pitching with a lead -- a big lead -- is a new thing for him.   Perez did not expect the Yankees to provide him with eight runs yesterday afternoon at the Stadium. Usually, he's lucky to get three. And with Bernie Williams, Don Mattingly and Danny Tartabull on the disabled list, the Yankee offense should be suffering, not racking up the hits.

wiki_events.headline: Dobrinja mortar attack: Thirteen are killed and 133 wounded when Serb mortar shells are fired at a soccer game in Dobrinja, west of Sarajevo.

pages.title: Dobrinja mortar attack
pages.description: 1993 massacre of Bosnian civilians in Sarajevo
pages.abstract: The Dobrinja mortar attack was a massacre which occurred at 10:20 a.m. on 1 June 1993, in Dobrinja, a suburb west of Sarajevo in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Two mortar rounds were fired from Serb-held positions, hitting a football pitch where youths put on an impromptu game on the first day of the Muslim holiday Kurban Bajram. Approximately 200 people were in attendance to watch the game. The United Nations placed the official death toll stemming from the mortar attack at 13, with 133 wounded. At the time it was the deadliest event involving civilians since the imposition of sanctions against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia by the United Nations one year prior.

pages.title: Dobrinja
pages.description: Neighborhood in Sarajevo Canton, Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bosnia and Herzegovina
pages.abstract: Dobrinja is a neighbourhood in the western outskirts of Sarajevo, part of the municipality of Novi Grad. It is estimated to have a population of 25,063 inhabitants. Its name comes from the short river Dobrinja that flows through it. It is today organised in four local communities. Dobrinja lies just north of Sarajevo International Airport.

pages.title: Sarajevo
pages.abstract: Sarajevo is the capital and largest city of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with a population of 275,524 in its administrative limits. The Sarajevo metropolitan area including Sarajevo Canton, East Sarajevo and nearby municipalities is home to 555,210 inhabitants. Located within the greater Sarajevo valley of Bosnia, it is surrounded by the Dinaric Alps and situated along the Miljacka River in the heart of the Balkans, a region of Southern Europe.

nytimes_articles.abstract: The Czechs and Europe. Regarding "EC and the East: Just Say No" (Business/Finance, April 20) by Reginald Dale:. The Czechs always were in Europe, albeit cut off for some 40 years. If it is beyond dispute that the Czech Republic is not yet ready

nytimes_articles.headline: As 4-Year-Old Is Buried, Accused Killer Is Arraigned
nytimes_articles.abstract: He was a little boy who liked seesaws and swings, rice and beans, slang words like "chill." He went to Sunday school. He was fond of Diana Ross. He would tag along after the woman he called his mommy as she moved from room to room.   Kayesean Blackledge was rehearsing for his first graduation at Salem Baptist Nursery School in Jersey City before his songs and his laughter were cut short on May 20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton's Order on M.I.A. Data a Small Shift
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's announcement on Monday that he had ordered the declassification of all but a tiny fraction of military documents on Americans who did not return from the war in Southeast Asia represents only a small change from Bush Administration policy.    In July, President Bush ordered the declassification of 200,000 pages of State Department papers and 2,600 pages of Central Intelligence Agency materials related to the 2,260 American servicemen listed as unaccounted for in the Vietnam War, Administration officials said today. The officials added that in 1991 Congress ordered that the military declassify 1.5 million pages of Defense Department documents.

nytimes_articles.headline: Too Many Musicians? An Overhaul at Juilliard -- A special report.; A New Juilliard for a More Challenging Era
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sun was beating strongly on the plaza in front of the Juilliard School on a recent weekday, but the real heat was coming from another source. Before an audience of students sprawled on the white stone or crowded around a buffet table set up for the school's year-end picnic, Eugene Park was going through an ear-splitting, high-voltage rendition of a Hungarian czardas by Vittorio Monti.   This was a crowd that knew its Monti and liked what it was hearing. Mr. Park, a first-year student whose face was obscured by long hair, rocked back and forth on his heels in the slower sections, building anticipation, then let it rip in the fast passages, bow hairs snapping as he punished the strings of his electric violin. It was Paganini with a few dashes of Pete Townshend thrown in for extra attitude. The students clapped and whistled, grateful perhaps for diversion from the week's main focus: solo performances before a faculty jury to determine their final grades. The Advent of Change    It was a scene at odds with the traditional picture of Juilliard, the most prestigious conservatory in the United States, and perhaps in the world, one whose graduates account for about 20 percent of the musicians in the Big Five American orchestras (and half of those in the New York Philharmonic).

nytimes_articles.headline: ATTACK ON YELTSIN STEPPED UP BY FOE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi stepped up his attacks on President Boris N. Yeltsin today and called on the Russian Parliament to disband his Government "completely and immediately."   Mr. Rutskoi's new offensive came as Russia's warring political factions head into a major battle over a new constitution, which Mr. Yeltsin will put on the table this weekend at a specially summoned conference. The conference, which opens on Saturday, was expanded today, as Mr. Yeltsin ordered each of the Russian Federation's 88 regions and territories to double their representation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panthers Expected to Name Neilson Coach
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Florida Panthers scheduled a news conference for today amid speculation they will name the former Rangers coach ROGER NEILSON as their first head coach. GREG BOURIS, a Panthers spokesman, said that "with all the speculation recently, I'm sure it won't be a major surprise."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Music (and Traffic) Go Round With a Beat
nytimes_articles.abstract: JOSE (CHEO) DIAZ is a J.D., M.C. and D.J.   Yes, an explanation is in order.   By day, Mr. Diaz is a traffic court judge in Queens, presiding over a parade of speeders and red-light runners who try to fast-talk their way out of fines and license suspensions. But at night, Cheo changes venue and does his own smooth-talking as a master of ceremonies at nightclubs and a radio disk jockey of a salsa show on WKCR-FM.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stony Brook President Plans to Step Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. John H. Marburger, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, announced today that he would step down and return to teaching, ending a 13-year tenure marked by strains to maintain academic standards as state aid steadily declined.   In announcing his resignation, Dr. Marburger said he would leave his $146,000 position as soon as a successor is found, which he estimated would take up to a year. He pointed out that when he was appointed to the post in 1980 he said he planned to stay for only 10 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: After Jordan Does Damage, Riley Finds Another Target
nytimes_articles.abstract: Disturbed that Michael Jordan has attempted 17 more free throws than Patrick Ewing during their last two games, Pat Riley cried foul today.   Riley's complaints about the officiating provided more intrigue leading up to Game 5 of the Eastern Conference championship, the most critical game of the Knicks' season. The four-of-seven-game series is tied at two games apiece and the scene shifts Wednesday night to Madison Square Garden, where New York has won 27 consecutive games.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemalan Who Grabbed Power Is Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Guatemalan military forced President Jorge Serrano Elias from office today with the backing of political parties, business executives and some civic groups. Eight days ago, Mr. Serrano seized nearly dictatorial powers with the Army's support.   As Mr. Serrano sat under guard and hundreds of demonstrators chanted at the gates of the National Palace for a civilian government, military commanders worked out a settlement with political leaders and jurists late this afternoon to restore democracy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez Turns Rout Into Rousing Comeback
nytimes_articles.abstract: She was on the run, on the defensive, and, after two sets on the French Open's red clay against Steffi Graf, Jennifer Capriati was on her way home to Florida.    Not so with another underdog, fifth-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez, who resurrected herself from the brink of elimination against third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini in a bizarre quarterfinal encounter that produced five match points for each player, started under picnic conditions in bright sunshine and ended with the court swathed in evening shadows.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Admits Big Changes In Budget Plan Are Needed
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton conceded today that he would have to reduce his tax proposals and cut spending more deeply to get his economic program through the Senate, but he held out the hope that his plans to put more money into education and job training would not be gutted in the process.   In a speech here, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that large changes in his budget plan were inevitable and set out five areas that he did not want touched. He asked negotiators to leave intact his goal of reducing the deficit by $500 billion over four years, to approve only those new taxes that affect the rich more than the poor, to keep measures for small business and for the working poor and to retain spending cuts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report in the Benefits column of Styles of The Times on Sunday and a about a benefit last evening at the Pierre Hotel for CASA, a drug education organization, misstated the group's full name. It is the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Genetically Altered Foods Need Regulating
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The "cool look at genetically altered foods" in Jane Brody's May 19 Personal Health column is in our view a naive look.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cubans Tired of Castro, Si. Fear Him? No.
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   If one were to believe the rhetoric of those Cubans in exile represented by "Cubans in Exile Want Embargo to Go On" by Vicente Echerri (letter, May 21), one would expect to find Cuba some sort of vast prison camp. Having recently returned from Cuba, I must object.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; A Fragile Truce
nytimes_articles.abstract: Those veterans of Vietnam who jeered and booed the President this Memorial Day did a disservice to themselves and to the conflict in which they served.    More than that, it was they, not the man they reviled as a draft-dodger and a coward, who did a disservice to those nearly 60,000 others whose names are etched in stone on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Japanese Gig for '60s Jazz
nytimes_articles.abstract: - Few Japanese would risk walking away from a secure job to pursue a personal ambition. But Tetsuo Hara felt the time had come.For years, the record producer had dreamed of reissuing the early avant-garde jazz recordings from the 1960s that were his awakening to music as art.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reflections on a Quarter-Century Behind Bars; Can the Restricted Life on the Inside Offer Lessons for the Free Life on the Outside?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The city street was a slash of bright sunshine and teeming noise as William Wooden emerged from prison after 25 years inside, squinting at the outside.    This murderer-robber, and duly punished ex-convict, 55 years old and determined to salvage something from time, re-entered the slipstream of free humanity from an old warehouse building in Queens, now a holding center where inmates shed their prison greens and muster back out in mufti.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: CARDINAL O'CONNOR LOOKS BACK   Reflecting on nearly 10 turbulent years at the helm of New York's Roman Catholic Archdiocese, John Cardinal O'Connor said that he might have gone too far at times in leaps of faith that thrust him and his church into secular politics -- from his implicit criticism of Geraldine A. Ferraro in 1984 to his loose alliance with Pat Robertson last month. A1.  NEW YORK CITY  A LITTLE BOY IS MOURNED   A tape cassette recording of his classmates, their voices raised in song, was placed gently inside a small veiled white casket with Kayesean Blackledge, a 4-year-old whose lifeless body was found beaten and strangled at the base of a garbage chute at a Brooklyn housing project. B3.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Their Balkan Quarrel
nytimes_articles.abstract: - Much has been said of the inability of the European Community, the United States and Russia to stop the carnage in Bosnia. The powers that be have been called cynical, cowardly, muddleheaded, indecisive or selfish for failing to bring the war to an end. But things ought to be put in perspective.

nytimes_articles.headline: Black Mediator Serves As a Bridge to Koreans
nytimes_articles.abstract: In her baseball cap and baby blue running suit, Karen Gunn is an unlikely diplomat, shuttling in her rusting Toyota from one haggard business strip to the next, checking out wig shops and shoe stores.   Ms. Gunn, a black woman working for Koreans, roams the ghettos of Chicago, where Korean merchants and their black customers have formed a nervous truce after years of antipathy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Movies Discover Black Cowboys and Cavalry
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your screen review of "Posse" (May 14) can't seem to forgive its director, Mario Van Peebles, for trying to duel with "the flagrant distortions of the past."

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Connie Chung at the Anchor Desk
nytimes_articles.abstract: So as of last night it is "The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather and Connie Chung." Why the addition of the last three words? One canard -- that CBS News executives decided a proven favorite would help the second-place program's ratings -- must be dismissed out of hand. Such an explanation would be disrespectful to CBS News, unflattering to Mr. Rather, patronizing to Ms. Chung and sexist to boot. Definitely impermissible.   Another possibility is that after all these years of solitary stardom, Mr. Rather found the part of his job that consists of spending a few minutes five nights a week reciting headlines and doing 20-second leads into other people's stories onerous or tedious, and begged his employers for relief, or at least company. Maybe with a helpmeet in place, he plans to get out the old bush jacket and visit more scenes of catastrophe.

nytimes_articles.headline: McElroy Signs With Chiefs
nytimes_articles.abstract: REGGIE McELROY, the starting right tackle for the Los Angeles Raiders last season, has signed a three-year contract with the Kansas City Chiefs.

nytimes_articles.headline: CAMBODIAN RULERS ASK FOR NEW VOTE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Government threatened today to reject the results of last week's elections and warned of the possibility of "insurrections and riots" if the United Nations refused to hold new voting in four provinces.   The United Nations rejected the call for new polling, saying that the Government had failed to produce evidence of serious vote fraud in the four provinces: Phnom Penh, the capital; Battambang; Kompong Chhnang and Prey Veng. Together they account for 35 of the 120 seats in the new national assembly, which will be responsible for drafting a constitution and forming a new government.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guatemalan Ousted
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Guatemalan military forced President Jorge Serrano Elias from office with the backing of political parties, business executives and some civic organizations. The move came eight days after the President had seized nearly dictatorial powers with the support of the army.    Article, page A8.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1918: German Offensive

nytimes_articles.headline: Wayne's Whirl As the Kings Win Game 1
nytimes_articles.abstract: It seems that Wayne Gretzky can do it all and then some. In addition to scoring once and assisting on the three other Los Angeles goals tonight, he accidentally put one puck into his own net, on behalf of the Montreal Canadiens. Perhaps, for his next act, Gretzky can drive the Zamboni or sing two national anthems in two languages.   The show by Gretzky, and two goals by teammate Luc Robitaille, were the highlights of a tedious 4-1 Kings' victory in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals at the Forum. Game 2 of the four-of-seven-game series is here on Thursday night.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1893: Newfangled Stamp

nytimes_articles.headline: Injustice in Texas
nytimes_articles.abstract: Texas leads the nation in lethal injections and the number of people on death row, in part because of the legal rules that have exposed Gary Graham to execution early tomorrow. One state law denies him a hearing on new evidence and substantial claims of innocence. Another state law, since repealed, made his youth irrelevant to his sentence and arguments for mercy unavailable.    Gov. Ann Richards agreed that the case raised significant questions of innocence, and in late April granted a one-month delay. Mr. Graham's execution will mean that the state's Board of Pardons and Paroles chose to ignore her. It will also be another grim trophy for the current U.S. Supreme Court majority, which seems determined to make the death penalty easier to enforce even if it has to legislate new rules to smooth the way.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shandling's Blend of Fact and Parody
nytimes_articles.abstract: One wall of Garry Shandling's office here is covered with newspaper clippings describing the latest twists and turns in the late-night television game: a little bit of Letterman, a little bit of Leno, some Arsenio Hall and Chevy Chase.   Mr. Shandling could easily have included several recent headlines about another prospective late-night talk-show host: Garry Shandling. Back in April, when NBC was pursuing Mr. Shandling to take over Mr. Letterman's "Late Night" show in the 12:35 A.M. slot, it was all over the newspapers. There still are rumors that CBS will offer him a show to follow David Letterman on that network.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wishing Won't Do. Regarding "Star Wars Is Dead! Long Live BMDO!" (Opinion, May 22) by Charles Krauthammer:. The Ballistic Missile Defense Organization, successor to the "star wars" program, demonstrates a kind of wishful thinking: Devi

nytimes_articles.headline: Navajos Are Asked to Aid Effort to Contain an Illness
nytimes_articles.abstract: The leader of the country's largest Indian tribe went on tribal radio today to beseech his people in their own language to cooperate with the medical investigators searching for the cause of a mysterious illness that has killed 12 people since March.
